video.aria: Moving averages (MAs) are popular technical analysis tools used to smooth price data and help identify trends and reversals.

overview.title: Overview
bullets: Moving averages (MAs) smooth price data to make trends and reversals easier to spot.
The two most common types are Simple Moving Average (SMA) and Exponential Moving Average (EMA), which use different weighting methods.
MAs help traders identify trend direction, generate trade signals, and find dynamic support and resistance.

items.title: Simple Moving Average (SMA)
items.desc: An average of recent prices with equal weighting—great for general trend analysis.

items.title: Exponential Moving Average (EMA)
items.desc: Weights recent prices more heavily—faster response to market changes; favored in fast markets.

items.title: Trend Identification
items.desc: Price above the MA suggests a bullish trend; price below the MA suggests a bearish trend.

items.title: Moving Average Crossover
points: Golden Cross: A short-term MA (e.g., 50-day) crosses above a long-term MA (e.g., 200-day) — bullish signal.
Death Cross: A short-term MA crosses below a long-term MA — bearish signal.

items.title: Dynamic Support and Resistance
points: Uptrends: MAs often act as dynamic support where price bounces.
Downtrends: MAs can act as dynamic resistance, pushing price lower.

items.title: Moving Average Ribbon Strategy
points: Setup multiple MAs (e.g., 10, 20, 50, 100, 200) to create a ribbon.
When the ribbon is aligned in one direction, it often signals a strong trend.

limitations.title: Limitations
bullets: Moving averages are lagging indicators and can react slowly to sudden market changes.
They can produce false signals in choppy or ranging markets.
